Header:
This sample depicts a cross section of a murine heart acquired 1 day after induction of a myocardial infarction using a minimally invasive, non-reperfusion model. 
Imaging was performed using the Lunaphore COMET (PA) platform with a 12-plex antibody panel.

Raw data is available at: https://www.synapse.org/Synapse:syn51449054/files/
Manuscript: https://doi.org/10.1101/2024.05.20.594955

Waypoints.Name: 1 day post-MI - Overview
Waypoints.Description:
In the acute phase of myocardial infarction (MI), infiltrating immune cells play a key role in cardiac healing and subsequent remodelling. Utilizing a minimally invasive MI induction model and combining targeted transcriptomic and proteomic approaches on heart cross sections in the acute phase of MI, we were able to observe a novel mode of immune infiltration to the infarcted heart via the endocardium - the inner layer of the heart.

Our findings report a strong increase specifically for monocytes/macrophages expressing Ccr2 in the endocardial infarct zone, peaking at 24 hours after MI, which is why we present the Minerva story for this specific time point.

Waypoints.Name: Region annotation
Waypoints.Description:
We have annotated the following regions based on the cardiac geometry, Tnnt2 and Ankrd1 signal presence, and proximity to the endocardial layer:
 - LV lumen: Left ventricular lumen.
 - Infarct core: Annotated as the region characterized by low Tnnt2 and high Ankrd1 intensity in which the infarct is transmural. If the infarct is not transmural, this is guided by the heart geometry.
 - Border zone: Encapsulates non-infarct injured regions, as well as the surrounding 5-cell thick layer of uninjured cells.
 - Epicardial infarct zone: Adjacent to the infarct core, the 3 to 5 cell thick region adjacent to the epicardial layer.
 - Endocardial infarct zone: Adjacent to the infarct core, the region between the lumen and injured tissue. This region includes the endocardial layer, as well as adjacent Ankrd1-  Tnnt2+ cardiomyocytes.
 - Remote endocardial region: Near-endocard region in an area remote of the infarct annotated with a comparable thickness to the near-MI endocardial region.
 - Background: Imaged area not containing cardiac tissue.
 - Artefact: area with artefacts - folds, dirt, bubbles, out-of-focus regions.

Waypoints.Name: Segmentation
Waypoints.Description:
For improved segmentation, we used WGA (wheat-germ-agglutinin) as a membrane marker and applied contrast-limited adaptive histogram equalization (CLAHE) prior to segmentation to be able to segment regions with very strong expression (e.g., staining in fibrotic regions).

Existing state-of-the-art models did not perform well on our data which is why we interactively trained a Cellpose 2 model on contrast-adjusted DAPI and WGA images of our data that could capture cardiomyocytes, as well as smaller cells only characterized by their nuclei.

Waypoints.Name: Immune landscape
Waypoints.Description:
The immune landscape of acute MI is diverse and dynamic, consisting of resident macrophages, infiltrating monocytes/macrophages, neutrophils as well as other myeloid cells.

Neutrophils are known to be the first immune cells to infiltrate, closely followed by Ccr2+ monocytes/macrophages.

It had been previously shown that immune cells infiltrate through the epicardial layer from the pericardium and from the border zones through vasculature.

Here we detected an additional infiltration route of monocytes/macrophages into the infarcted heart via the endocardium.

Waypoints.Name: Immune infiltration through the endocardial infarct zone
Waypoints.Description:
Here we see a zoom-ins on the endocardial infarct zone.

The staining indicates increased attachment and transmigration through the endocardium resulting in high density of Ccr2+ CD68+ monocytes/macrophages in the endocardial infarct zone.

Waypoints.Name: No immune infiltration through the remote-infarct endocardium
Waypoints.Description: When observing a comparable region remote to the infarct, infiltration events through the endocardial layer are much less pronounced.
